response.answer_text: YES… but it depends on the size of the hole and how detrimental it is to the audience member spotting it.  Writing is like a boat… one tiny leak in the boat and you might get to shore, but one BIG hole, or a thousand tiny ones will be your end. So what is a plot hole? According to Wikipedia, “In fiction, a plot hole, plothole or plot error is a gap or inconsistency in a storyline that goes against the flow of logic established by the story's plot. Such inconsistencies include things as illogical, unlikely or impossible events, and statements or events that contradict earlier events in the storyline. The term is more loosely also applied to "loose ends" in a plot – side-lined story elements that remain unresolved by the end of the plot.” Keep in mind… movies are about the suspension of disbelief… so noticing a plot hole, even a tiny one, can mean that the person noticing will enjoy the piece of work less. So even though I’m rating these in terms of small to large, (which is debatable, true, but I think it’s fitting and works with my boat example), everyone’s mileage may vary. For some, being in a leaky boat is something they can never unsee; for others, they’re more invested into getting to shore and grateful to get there regardless of the state of the ship! There’s also some subjectivity and objectivity at play here; for instance, in a military film, someone who has been in the military may spot the lead or other characters wearing the uniform improperly or handling weapons incorrectly due to their own experience. That can break the illusion for them, whereas someone with no experience in the military might miss it entirely. Worse, if the element at fault was critical to the plot… such as a type of military procedure the whole movie revolves around… you have a hole that’s a problem both subjectively AND objectively. With that said… Example: The Small Plot Hole The lead hero in an action film gets shot in the shoulder. A few minutes later, the same hero is thrown off a building, but manages to hang onto the edge and pull himself back up.This is a plot hole type that shows up SO MUCH in action fiction that it’s basically handwaved away and ignored. Logically, a character who was just shot… pretty much anywhere, but especially in “The Hollywood Flesh Wound”, (i.e. the shoulder), shouldn’t be able to pull up their body weight with that level of sustained injury. I’m using this as an example of the “inconsistency” type of plot hole. Most of what I put in this category is stuff that we know isn’t true in the real world, but is true in most fictional ones. It may or may not be experience breaking for the viewer. Similar examples: Character picks up a gun without ever having used one before and shoots the gun perfectly and has instant precision enough to hit their targetsThe chain smoker in the film swims underwater, holding their breath, with no issuesThe pregnant lady’s child is born under extreme circumstance outside of any healthcare facility, but when shown, the child and mother are basically clean as a whistle despite a couple patches of ‘makeup blood’.Big, fiery explosions and loud noises… IN SPACE!In all these cases, we, as the audience, know that what we’re watching isn’t logical, or realistic, or just flat out doesn’t make sense. But… if the hole is small enough, we will sometimes give it a pass, especially if we’ve seen it enough times to be a cliché. By that point, we just sort of ‘accept’ the rules of fiction and filmmaking, and kind of give it a free pass. Should we? Probably not, and most of us don’t, but even though we may ridicule those beats of the film, it may not have ruined the entire experience for us. It depends a lot on the fiction we’re watching. I never really complain about big explosions in space during Star Wars, because the original films never billed themselves as a ‘science fiction’ story the way that 2001: A Space Odyssey does. But I’ll CONSTANTLY rail on moments when “The Force” is changed or used incorrectly, because there’s a lot of screen time in six films that was used to establish exactly what it can and can not do. Example 2: The Medium-Sized Plot Hole  We’re told several times in several films that in order to beat the villain, you need to have training. We’re given examples where both untrained persons AND trained persons struggle against the villain or villains to reinforce this concept.  … and then it all changes on a dime and training never really mattered. Now we’re starting to have some problems. The medium-sized plot holes are heading into ship-sinking territory. They may not break your story, but these can be logic bombs that end up becoming a serious issue of debate… and THEN maybe break the story. If you ever rolled your eyes in a film, you probably watched a moment with at least a medium-sized plot hole. If the piece of work is moving fast enough, we might miss it altogether. Or, if the rest of the writing is really good, we might too invested into where the story is going to concentrate on the flaw in front of us. An emergency procedure, (possibly even the wrong one to save the victim’s life) is being performed by a non-professional using crude or inappropriate tools… and somehow actually works. (i.e. “Hollywood Medicine” such as an emergency tracheotomy or removing a bullet)Bad guys who are supposedly expert shots can’t land a hit, non-expert good guys have zero trouble hitting same bad guys.A device that is supposed to vaporize water in liquid form is unleashed on a city; however, since humans are over 70% water, humans should have been affected as well, but in the film, only water in pipes is affected.Star Trek famously uses ships to explore space and has a shaky set of rules about their transporters… until J.J. Abrams Star Trek films show us that you can use a teleporter to teleport accurately to ships in the middle of warp flight or to other planets across the galaxy, despite any range or power issues… which begs the question, why would we even need ships anymore?If you stop and think about some of these, you think, “NO WAY!” But there’s a willing suspension of disbelief that many of us carry around with us when it comes to fiction. For these holes, logic is getting broken, sometimes by accident and sometimes on purpose in order to tell the story. We usually will criticize the accidental breaks in logic… especially if they have no justifications. For movies like “Batman Begins”, it’s a pretty big hole to never explain why a machine that vaporizes water as a weapon wouldn’t fry people as well. But the rest of the movie is so good, I usually just give this medium-sized plot hole a pass.  You’ve probably given some of these a pass yourself if you ever justified what you saw with your own continuity, reasoning, or story. Who hasn’t gotten into a debate with someone over their favorite movie and justified moments by saying, “well, the character probably had ____________ experience off-screen, or before the film started”. Justifications like this about events we don’t see in the film but we *think* could be a plausible reason to explain that hole not being plugged is often enough for us to just keep rolling along. For instance: “Well, Wayne Enterprises wasn’t in the business of making lethal, offensive weapons. In fact, the armaments we see Bruce use that were created by his company are items like survival gear, climbing harnesses, tents, and bridge-making vehicles. It’s totally possible the weapon was DESIGNED to be humane and not hurt human beings.” Do we see this justification in the movie? Nope. But it does it make sense? Yes… it definitely could. So with our own explanation in mind, we kind of rationalize it for ourselves, and just move on. Example 3: THE LARGE PLOT HOLE. (Mary Sues, Deus Ex Machina, and Plot Armor, OH MY!)  If you’re a writer, you go through several editors hoping that this never happens. It doesn’t mean that it can’t… or won’t… happen, but typically if you have a big plot hole in your film, the overall work is going to suffer for it. If your piece of work is really, really good… you might survive this. But is it a risk you really want to take? In a world where everyone is surviving the zombie apocalypse with firearms and their wits, scared to death of getting bitten and turning, this character is both IMMUNE to the virus and has PSYCHIC powers, despite none of the heroes from the source material having either. (Resident Evil Film franchise)Our hero is told they can never interfere with human history. After his girlfriend dies in an accident, the character demonstrates a power we’ve never seen them use before as they circle around the Earth and somehow rewind time to save her… by interfering with human history. And if he could do this at any time he wants… why doesn’t he go back in time and save any of his parents? (Richard Donner’s Superman)Our hero is given a set of magical slippers at the start of the film and set off on a quest to find a wizard to help her get home. At the end of the film, she’s told that ALL SHE HAS TO DO IS CLICK THE HEELS OF THOSE SHOES TOGETHER. So why wasn’t she just told at the start? (The Wizard of Oz)“We got problems.” - Dwayne Hicks, Aliens  Uh-oh. Couldn’t have said it better myself, Dwayne. (Aliens, by the way is one of my favorite movies of all time, and it at least tries to justify MOST of the plot holes. Not all… but most.) A big plot hole can be a huge blemish on a work. Richard Donner’s “Superman” is a great example. As soon as we give Superman the ability to reverse time inexplicably, all the questions start: Why not go back in time and save his dad?Why not go back in time and save KRYPTON?!Superman can’t do that in the comics! Why can he do it here?!It’s like showing Jedi with healing powers 9 movies into a franchise. If this power was always around, why wasn’t anyone using it? Even if it was shown outside of these movies, what are the chances your audience has seen it? You have to write your film with the answers self-contained inside of it. Otherwise, suddenly, the plot hole can potentially invalidate EVERYTHING around it and make for a terrible film. Remember what I was talking about with immersion? Well, seeing a character like Alice in Resident Evil running around with psychic powers and blowing things up with just her mind in a film series named famously for video games with non-super powered protagonists made for some really big problems. This is what we call a Mary Sue. She’s ridiculously overpowered and special, way beyond any other character in the series, and not just because she’s the lead; she’s special in a way that breaks the logic of that universe. She’s also got a wicked case of Plot Armor… she’s never in any actual danger, which stands out even more since she’s in a type of fiction that works best when anyone can die. Superman, (as dearly as I love 99% of that film), suffers from the Deus Ex Machina problem. This is a magical solution that just arrives with no set up at from any earlier part of the story, and is quite frankly, very outside of what we know to be ‘true’ for the movie thus far. That’s a really big problem, and typically a signature of really bad writing.  So in the end, I think Plot Holes can matter a lot, depending on the size and scope of the whole. Tiny ones… I can usually let go under most circumstances. But big ones that reveal bad writing or universe breaking problems with the entire story… no. Those can be deal breakers.

Often times, what people call "plot holes" are actually manifestations of their own based on a number of different factors, including whether they liked the movie or not.   If they enjoyed the movie, they won't be thinking twice about anything beyond that fact.   If they didn't enjoy the movie, their mind will be picking at any little piece it can to communicate the emotions that they are feeling after watching said movie.   That's the truth.   Do some movies have gaping plot holes?  Yes.  Mostly due to poor editing, poorly structured scripts that likely make it into production based solely off of concept, casting, etc.   But a majority of the time, plot holes are manifestations of the viewer.   To go further, people have to understand that a movie cannot cover every waking moment of a character and story.  It would be impossible.  So screenwriters and filmmakers are required to give an audience the broad strokes.  They are asked to piece together a sequence of events and moments amidst the chaos of conflict that is thrust upon characters.  The loose ends that do and will exist and then tied up as best as possible.  Some films succeed in that more than others.  So, do plot holes matter?  No.  What matters is if the filmmakers engaged the viewer enough to not seek out the plot holes.

Plot holes both matter and don't matter depending on.  Who wrote it.What format it is in. The audience expectations.The delivery method.The people who pay for it's development and delivery. The frequency and gaping size of plot holes. The quality of material around the plot hole. To some writers plot holes are an anathema, they drive them mad and so to them they matter a lot, on the whole this kind of writer considers themselves an artist, they tend prefer the cheaper mediums of delivery such as Novels and plays, they also tend to be poor. They write for their audience. To other writers plot holes can be forgiven, if tricks of pace and misdirection can be implemented to minimise the impact. These writers are skilled pragmatists, they consider themselves craftsmen, they are more likely to actually make money, they tend to work in the mediums that are more expensive to deliver to the audience such as film and TV. They write for demographics. It is hard to get away with plot holes in a novel or a play, film and TV are wide open, in part this is because of the audience expectations and the level of concentration required to consume the story. The more concentration required to consume the story the harder it is to hide the holes.  This is because the type of person who likes to concentrate on their entertainment is the type of person who likes to analyse everything. They care about plot holes, they love to find them, and some, not all, use it to temporarily alleviate their own sense of personal disappointment through a fleeting feeling of 'I could have written that' superiority. On the whole publishers care about the authors integrity and pride, they think of them as the tallent, if the author cares about something then they care. An unhappy author is a little like an unhappy teenager, they do nothing but eat and avoid showers, it is not good for business. Film and TV producers see writers as a necessary evil, they don't give a single solitary fuck about anyones integrity and pride, least of all the writer.  Writers are the annoying people who don't write the changes fast enough. They don't want a writer whining on about plot holes particularly when they appear after the changes they have requested, particularly when it is blazingly obvious to them that that the punters dont notice that kind of thing anyway.  Which they don't when the real reason they are sat infront of the screen is the exact oposite of concentrating.  They are engaged in a form of zen meditation where really they are just trying to clear their minds with something that stimulates the more exitable, thinky, parts of the brain, so that the rest can just hang out, doing nothing, with out going a bit cabin-fevery-mental.  To these people plot holes are only relevant when it registers through this reduced mental capacity, the plot holes have to be frequent and gaping (see "Rancid Aluminium") to make any major impact and sometimes if surrounded by enough romance / comedy / action, even machine gun holes do not smash the great pane of wilful-disengagement protecting the critical-faculties of most 'punters'.  In summary: Plot holes are an anathema - catastrophic, an aceptable downside to getting paid - not so bad,Something to be avoided - bad,something that is distasteful but elicits a form of smug superiority - good,some that can effect authors self esteem and so effect their prolificacy - bad, and except in the most extreem example totally irrelevant - Irrelevant, So again Plot holes are: Catastrophic, not so bad, bad, good, bad and irrelevant.

Here are some pros on the subject: In Patrick McGilligan’s Backstory 1, screenwriter, Richard Maibaum, described working with Alfred Hitchcock on FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT: “I was writer number thirty... primarily I rewrote the... part of the old statesman who was kidnapped. (Hitchcock) said to me, ‘Did you read what we’ve got?’ Which was half a screenplay. I said, ‘Yes.’ He said, ‘What do you think about it?’ I replied, ‘It’s not very logical.’ He grimaced and said, ‘Oh, dear boy, don’t be dull. I’m not interested in logic, I’m interested in effect. If the audience ever thinks about logic, it’s on their way home after the show, and by that time, you see, they’ve paid for their tickets.’” In François Truffaut’s book-length interview with Alfred Hitchcock, Hitchcock, they discussed THE THIRTY-NINE STEPS, and Hitchcock commented, “‘What I liked in (the film) are the swift transitions...’ and he describes the succession of elaborate sequences in the film. Then he says, “‘The rapidity of those transitions heightens the excitement...’” Truffaut responds, “‘It’s a style that tends to do away with anything utilitarian... (a style) that’s extremely satisfying to audiences and yet often irritates the critics... they will analyze the script, which, of course, doesn’t stand up to logical analysis... a thoroughly casual approach to the plausible.’” And Hitchcock replies, “‘I’m not concerned with plausibility; that’s the easiest part of it, so why bother?’” He describes the scene with the ornithologist in THE BIRDS, wherein she just happens to be there at that moment, and he says, “‘I could have made up three scenes just to give that woman a logical reason for being there, but they would have been completely uninteresting... Aside from the waste of time, they make for gaps or flaws in the picture. Let’s be logical. If you’re going to analyze everything in terms of plausibility or credibility, then no fiction script can stand up to that approach, and you wind up doing a documentary.’”     In Peter Bogdanovich’sWho The Devil Made It, director Howard Hawks, discussing THE BIG SLEEP, had this to say about the subject: “We were arguing about who killed so-and-so and we couldn’t come to any decision. So we wired the novel's author, Raymond Chandler. He wired back a name, and we wired him saying, ‘But, it couldn’t have been him—he was at the beach at that time.’ Making this picture, I realized that you don’t really have to have an explanation for things. As long as you make good scenes you have a good picture—it doesn’t matter...” And in his interview in Screenwriters’ Masterclass, Ted Tally, responding to a question on the need for logic: “No, I never worry about that kind of thing, what (director) Jonathan (Demme) called ‘Refrigerator questions.’... he said, ‘You’ve seen the movie, you’ve enjoyed it, you get home and open the refrigerator and say, ‘Wait a minute, how could that guy have done that?’... If it doesn’t occur to you until you get to the refrigerator, it’s not important enough for us to worry about.’” Finally, here's lecturer and author Robert McKee's take: In Robert McKee’s book on screenwriting, Story, he describes three great movies, CASABLANCA, CHINATOWN, and THE TERMINATOR, each with a significant flaw or hole in its plot. After laying out the flaws in detail, he points out that holes needn’t be closed if the audience is likely never to notice them, thanks either to positioning or lack of prominence in the story-line. These examples and more are discussed in my book, LATERAL SCREENWRITING.

In my opinion, no, not really. When I say they “don’t matter” what I mean to say is movies generally do not live and die by their plot holes. If you notice the plot holes it usually says more about you or they are indicative of much larger issues with the film (such as the acting). Here’s a list of things way, way more important than plot holes. The cinematography (arguably the most important)The styleThe color gradingThe dialogueThe actingScene selection and set upSets and propsThe special effects (more important now)CastingIf I were to even include plot holes, I could probably think of about twenty or thirty more things. Plot holes are generally things only nerds who are confused about what they are watching nitpick movies over. Nothing against nerds - but there is a toxicity to that kind of outlook. I mean really, you’re watching a movie where a radioactive spider gave a teenager superpowers and complaining about how Peter Parker ended up inside a closet with no windows. It’s really f***ing stupid. Movies are not real life (not that real life is particularly logical either) - and, in my opinion, most movies are not trying to depict real life with the exception of Documentaries. Even movies about real-life events are theatrical artistic renderings of those events. For example, most courtrooms don’t feature heated arguments that end in “YOU CAN’T HANDLE THE TRUTH!”, but those scenes do an excellent job of replicating the tension one might feel inside of a contentious court proceeding. In a way, movies are more about the perception of reality, than reality. They weave together a montage to give you the impression of what a story feels like. That emotional component is far more important than the logical one. Could you imagine a horror movie where everyone behaved logically and there were no plot holes? It wouldn’t be scary. Can you imagine a comedy where people behaved and acted like adults? It wouldn’t be funny. Or for the guys who complain “you know a woman couldn’t beat up a large man” - yeah, well neither could Bruce Lee, that dude was 100 lbs soaking wet.  You’d rather be watching this? There are also rules for writing scripts, directing scenes and even comedy that disregards a lot of “plot logic” to make things that are more compelling. There’s a ton of stunt choreography (done by people that know how to fight, mind you) that sacrifices practicality for theatricality. Movies assume you are reasonably intelligent enough to know that you are watching a movie and these decisions are made in service of that. Unfortunately, maybe I’m just giving audiences too much credit.

They do if you notice them.  If you don't then it's not an issue. Often this is not a problem with the size of the plot hole as much as the rest of the movie. If the viewer is having a great time and really enjoying themselves then they're unlikely to notice plot holes and let them fly by. If they're not having such a good time they'll jar and take the viewer out of the movie. Every James Bond movie has plot holes and problems with it's story but usually I'm having so much fun watching that I don't care. I'm taken along for the ride and while I can spot a major flaw when I'm reflecting after the event it doesn't take me out of the movie. But Moonraker was such a bad movie that it wasn't distracting me at all. The tedious action sequences and lack of any originality left me bored and disinterested enough when I first saw it that the plot holes stood out like gaping chasms (and they're huge in Moonraker).  There's a popular gif going around about Empire Strikes Back and the fact that the timing just doesn't work when Luke's storyline verges away from the crew of the Millenium Falcoln.    This is an excellent point but I wonder how many people realised this when they were watching the movie. I didn't notice when I saw it and I'm guessing most others didn't either. We were having so much fun watching the movie that they flew a plothole under our radar and we missed it. If they'd tried that in the prequels when I was yawning and squirming in my seat with the tedium of it all I would definitely have spotted it.

Yes, of course they do. You can't kick dirt over them and expect the audience or whoever is reading your script to be forgiven. Don't get lazy. Fix it no matter how long it takes.  Be in control of your plot.Is your story coming together or falling apart? I would say they don't strictly matter depending on the context of the plot hole, let's take something which has always bothered me with the terminator series, no not all the rubbish wibbly wobbly timey wimey stuff that made no sense towards the end films. My plot hole gripe with the terminator is this,  The fact that every single t800 in the film bar from the first one that breaks into the rebel bunker in the original film during the flash back, looks exactly like this. Now this is supposed to be the best infiltration machine ever invented so why do they all look like Arnold Schwarzenegger surely all we need to do is keep a eye out for Arnold Schwarzenegger possibly carrying a box of roses and almost definitely wearing sunglasses and we have found our terminator, this is made worse by the point in salvation where they are shown making another copy of Arnold Schwarzenegger which is very quickly dispatched with so it cannot even be argued that this is the same terminator passed around alternative timelines it simply doesn't make any sense from any point if view, is it a plot inconsistency yes does it matter or detract from the films ( bearing in mind the films from the third up are crap for completely separate reasons) absolouty not.

No, I think there’s a lot of social currency to being a critic at the moment. It has always been there but the people most into it have mass media platforms now. So there’s a lot of doctrine developing as is the case when critics have too much say in the general conversation about a work of art (all my opinion btw). If someone likes your story they will like the plot holes, if they hate it they will hate them. All of the best stories ever told have massive plot holes. The stories that have followed humanity from the beginning of time have even bigger plot holes. Religious stories, allegories, children’s stories, fables, and any best selling or most critically acclaimed movie of any year has plot holes. All that matters is whether and individual likes or hates your story. A lot of people that are die-hard about Star Wars hate the plot holes of the new movies, but the plot holes in the old ones are their favorite parts of the story. They allow them to fill in the blank themselves. Plot holes are often used to justify a fan’s over-thinking of a work, which it’s self is a way to enjoy it after the experience is over. An entire fan-made universe of logic, stories and characters were built from trying to explain plot holes in the original three movies. All until the person wants to say ‘this thing sucks’ then they’re the worst thing ever.

To me, it depends on whether the plot hole actually affects the plot: If it doesn’t really matter to the plot, then it’s fine. For example, hearing explosions in outer space: we all know you wouldn’t really hear it in space - but we also know that silent movies are BORING. As long as it doesn’t affect the plot (as in: “Captain, there’s a ticking sound coming from the enemy ship - we should move away in case it explodes”), I’m willing to give them a pass. It is supposed to be entertainment, after all.But if it materially affects the plot, then I find it annoying. When a ship in orbit is shot, and it suddenly starts falling, that’s the kind of plot hole that bugs me.

If a person is left at the end of the story thinking more about what was wrong with it than the message the author was trying to convey than yes you have a major plot hole problem. I recently saw a movie where a huge part of the story revolved around humans making a manned flight to Titan, one of the moons of Saturn, in 2017.  What the hell? So the writers are saying that we are going to get our act together to the point that we completely bypass Mars, the Asteroid belt, Jupiter and just skip straight the moons of Saturn? And that we are going to do this in only 4 years! That bugged me the whole time after I heard it and for the next day. I mean seriously, I am going to probably still be driving the same car in four years, but mankind is going to skip from nixing the space shuttle program to a manned voyage to Titan? That bugged me. Seriously.  You want to know the major problem? I have spent far more time thinking about that one minor detail in the movie to most watchers than any quality points after. It did have great visuals and other interesting tid-bits, but if a plot hole is big enough it will suck you in and destroy any other aspect of the piece that might have been otherwise enjoyable.

As an actor and director, I must say that I can be more forgiving of plot holes than I can in character holes. By this, I mean when a character makes a choice that is unmotivated, and often uncharacteristic of them. Naturally, we're all inconsistent from time to time and may even seem unrecognizable to those who love us. But for the most part, characters have a predictable through-line, and when a character breaks the unspoken pact they have with an audience, we are more shaken up than we would be about a gap in the narrative. The through line, sometimes also called the 'spine,' was first suggested by Constantin Stanislavski as a simplified way for actors to think about characterization. He believed actors should not only understand what their character was doing, or trying to do, (their 'objective') in any given section of text, but should also strive to understand the through line which linked these objectives together and thus pushed the character forward through the narrative and towards their 'super-objective.' After all, that protagonist is our entry into the story. She's our Holden Caulfield, Ishmael, Nick Carraway...When we are forced to reconcile ourselves with conflicting narrative, decisions unmotivated by what that person hold's dear and strives for, or is delivered in clunky exposition or details at the wrong moments, we are forced out of the action -- alienated -- and lose faith is our hero and the story. Everything that we've learned is called into question. I would simply argue that a poorly written or inconsistent character can be just as devastating, if not more, than a frustrating plot hole.

Anything that pulls the viewer out of the story is a flaw that matters. Therefore if the plot hole pulls the viewer out of the story it matters.  If it doesn't, it doesn't.  Real life is full of plot holes.

Well let me see  That girl never wielded a light saber before. Phin was clueless about dulling. For somehow, both could manage and defend themselves without struggles against the supposed trained jedi and Sith apprentice.. People use the same bullshit excuse: “he was damaged by Chewbaca shotgun”. No, he was not that much hurt, a hurt from that damn gun would not let him to walk, you can’t defend yourself against a supposedly master duelist on sabers just with lucky. Realistic, Phin should at least lose some of his limbs and Rey would be killed and that’s it. It was a plot armour. Second problem  Phin grabs Capitain Phasma and obligate her to lower the shields of the huge new planet Death Star. Where they were? At some random machine spot, not a central terminal, just a random terminal. Its like accessing the Central Bank mainframe from any ATM you want, just go there, put a bunch of codes and you can transfer all the federal reserve to your account because you know the damn password. Yes… There are tons of shit like these, it makes a movie garbage instantly regardless how good is the CGI.

If the audience :- A) Notices and B) Gives a damn Then they do. But otherwise, they don’t. And even when they do, to you, they probably don’t. Because you are a fanboi/trekkie/whovian etc but the rest of the audience - MOST OF THE AUDIENCE, isn’t. That said, good writing tries to avoid plot holes if it can, but the process of filming can lead to some scenes being deleted that would have explained things, leading to apparent plot holes where none exist. And sometimes, EFFECT trumps plot.

There is kind of an unofficial rule of thumb that applies. If the plot hole is likely to be noticed by some people while they are watching the film then it's a problem and should have been addressed. But if its first mention is on some ubernerd discussion board a week later then you can live with it.

Do you still like your friend even if they didn't call you when they said they would?  That not calling was a plot hole. Will you survive?  Yes.  No storytelling is perfect and certainly not perfect for every listener - someone will have something to say about anything if they pick at it long enough.  Sometimes you just have to take the ride as it comes.

Enjoying a piece of fiction requires the suspension of disbelief. We know that what we are reading/watching is not true, but we pretend it is while we are enjoying the story. Obvious plot holes make this more difficult, and remind us that "This isn't real". They take us out of the story.
